question: Question_01_(a)
sols:
We seek to solve the system of congruences given by

\begin{align*}
x &\equiv 3 \mod{5}\\
x &\equiv 4 \mod{7}\end{align*}

The first equality says that $\displaystyle x = 3 + 5s$. Plugging into
the second yields $\displaystyle 3 + 5s \equiv 4 \mod{7}$. Simplifying
yields $\displaystyle 5s \equiv 1 \mod{7}$.

We can find the inverse of 5 by using the Euclidean algorithm however
since we are modulo 7, there is only 6 possible candidates so it is
faster to just try them all. Since
$\displaystyle 5\cdot3 \equiv 15 \equiv 1 \mod{7}$, we see that
$\displaystyle s \equiv 3 \mod{7}$. This is the same as
$\displaystyle s = 3 + 7t$. Back substituting gives
$\displaystyle x = 3 + 5(3 + 7t) = 18 + 35t$. So two possible answers
are given by 18 and 53.
hints: Use techniques related to the Chinese Remainder Theorem.
